Article

Daily reports about coronavirus disease (COVID-19)

Published 12.03.2020 Updated 15.04.2020

Here is a selection of data from the daily status reports about coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in Norway.

Here is a selection of data from the daily status reports about coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in Norway.

Les på norsk
Share/tip
Facebook Twitter Send by e-mail
Print

A status report is published every day at 13:00, based on data from the Norwegian Surveillance System for Communicable Diseases (MSIS), microbiological laboratories, Norwegian Intensive Care Register and Norwegian Syndromic Surveillance System.

Extract from daily COVID-19 report - Thursday 16 April 2020

Updated figures

Based on information about cased notified to the Norwegian Institute of Public Health: 

  • Total of 6 791 people with confirmed COVID-19, of which 115 were reported yesterday. Updated on the 15.04.2020 at 24:00.
  • 136 deaths have been notified to the NIPH (as of 16.04.2020 at 08:00). The average age is 84 years, the median age is 86 and 53 % are male.
  • A total of 133 707 have been tested for coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) (as of 15.04.2020 at 15:00). 
  • Number of people admitted to hospital (figures available from Norwegian Directorate of Health)

Intensive care patients

A total of 187 people in intensive care with confirmed coronavirus (SARS-CoV2) have been treated in intensive care units, of these, 63 are inpatients. The average age of the 187 confirmed patients is 62 years, and 76 % are male. 21 deaths have been reported.

(figures from Norwegian Intensive Care Register as of 16.04.2020 at 08:00.)

Age and gender 

The average age of cases is 47 years and 49 % are male.

Place of infection - Norway/abroad 

3 410 cases were infected in Norway, 1 595 cases were infected abroad. For 1 786 cases, the place of infection is unknown. Of those who were infected in Norway, 1 366 have been close contacts of one known infected case and 1 328 cannot be linked to a known infected cases, and 716 lack information about route of infection.

The number of positive tests per county are:
